prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: If the Panel determines that there exists more than one action that is appropriate for transfer and coordination or consolidation, it must determine an appropriate transferee district. On this important question neither the statute creating the Panel nor the Panel's own rules provide any guidance.

In many cases before the Panel, the selection of a transferee court is essentially the only decision to be made by the Panel because the appropriateness of transfer of the actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is overwhelmingly evident from the facts. The Panel has specifically indicated in some decisions that transfer is all but a foregone conclusion.[1] This result is especially likely if all or most of the parties agree that transfer is appropriate.[2]

The Panel in fact considers many factors in selecting a transferee district. These factors have been articulated in various decisions explaining the choice of a particular transferee district or rejecting the choices urged on the Panel by the litigants.

The decision regarding choice of a transferee district is related to the question of whether transfer is proper. The connection is not a clear one, but the existence of a suitable transferee court undoubtedly colors the Panel's judgment as to whether transfer should be ordered. This is not improper or the result of confusion—the fact that there is a suitable transferee court increases the likelihood that transfer will advance the just and efficient conduct of the actions.[3]
The specific factors considered by the Panel in selecting a transferee district fit into three categories:
Factors stated by the Panel in its decisions;
Factors probably relied on even though not discussed by the Panel; and
Factors not considered by the Panel, yet.

It is important for any attorney handling a matter before the Panel to consider all three classes of factors. Factors in the first class can be readily enumerated, and are listed below. They can and should be cited to the Panel in written memoranda. The second category includes factors that are more elusive, but no less important. These factors are also discussed in this chapter, although that discussion is inherently more speculative. The third class presents factors that may be most important for the lawyer to consider and evaluate. These factors cannot be learned by rote nor can they be enumerated. They are undoubtedly factors which would be persuasive to the Panel that either have been overlooked by attorneys or for which the proper case has not yet come before the Panel.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Silver Bridge Disaster, 311 F. Supp. 1345 (J.P.M.L. 1970); In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970); In re Western Liquid Asphalt, 309 F. Supp. 157, 158 (J.P.M.L. 1970); In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239, 241 (J.P.M.L. 1969). See generally Daniel, Note, An Analysis of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation's Selection of Transferee District and Judge, 78 Fordham L. Rev. 311 (2009).
